>> For pole balancing, it
>> turns out that you can solve it fastest with a minuscule population of
>> size under 20 total (that's for the whole population!).   That is
>> because smaller populations are greedier (they concentrate resources
>> on a small part of the search space) and apparently pole balancing
>> benefits greatly from greedy search.
> 
> That's really interesting. I have always thought the higher the
> population size the better.

Hello. I think Ken is saying that if you are measuring success by fewest
*evaluations* then it is better to have a lower population size. You need a
lot of generations because you need to mutationally tune the weights, but
you don't need that much diversity because you can just hill climb. So if
you cut the population size down, you get more generations for fewer
evaluations. 

I do think it is the case that, all else equal, a larger population will be
better (on average: individual runs may differ) if you are counting success
in terms of number of generations.
